title: How to Assemble a Sewing Kit

steps.headline: Find a suitable container to keep your sewing kit in.
steps.description: A little sewing basket or an open basket with a handle are ideal. Other choices include plastic boxes, tackle boxes, antique tins, cardboard boxes, etc.

steps.headline:
Gather together the following items for inclusion in the sewing kit:Needles - purchase a set of needles in differing sizes{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/4\/4d\/516403-2.1.jpg\/v4-459px-516403-2.1.jpg","bigUrl":"\/images\/thumb\/4\/4d\/516403-2.1.jpg\/aid516403-v4-728px-516403-2.1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":"728","bigHeight":"485","licensing":"

Image by: Uploader
\nLicense: Creative Commons<\/a>\n<\/p><\/div>"}
steps.description:
Pins - get a container of dressmaking pins{"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c8/516403-2.2.jpeg/v4-459px-516403-2.2.jpeg","bigUrl":"/images/thumb/c/c8/516403-2.2.jpeg/aid516403-v4-728px-516403-2.2.jpeg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":"728","bigHeight":"485","licensing":"

Image by: Uploader
License: Creative Commons

"} Scissors - keep one pair of quality sewing scissors in reserve just for needlework and sewing projects; don't use it for any other cutting{"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1d/516403-2.3.jpg/v4-459px-516403-2.3.jpg","bigUrl":"/images/thumb/1/1d/516403-2.3.jpg/aid516403-v4-728px-516403-2.3.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":"728","bigHeight":"485","licensing":"

Image by: Uploader
License: Creative Commons

"} Cotton thread - select the base colours white, black, navy blue and beige as a minimum; these are the most commonly used colours for sewing. Choose other colours as match items of clothing or favourite colours for clothes in your household. Over time you will build up your cotton collection with other colours and different thread types, such as metallic and invisible threads{"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bd/516403-2.4.jpg/v4-459px-516403-2.4.jpg","bigUrl":"/images/thumb/b/bd/516403-2.4.jpg/aid516403-v4-728px-516403-2.4.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":"728","bigHeight":"485","licensing":"

Image by: Uploader
License: Creative Commons

"} Thimble - always useful to help push a reticent needle through tough fabrics{"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/45/516403-2.5.jpg/v4-459px-516403-2.5.jpg","bigUrl":"/images/thumb/4/45/516403-2.5.jpg/aid516403-v4-728px-516403-2.5.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":"728","bigHeight":"485","licensing":"

Image by: Uploader
License: Creative Commons

"} Buttons - keep all of the buttons and thread pieces that come attached to new clothing purchases, along with some spare buttons{"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0a/516403-2.6.jpg/v4-459px-516403-2.6.jpg","bigUrl":"/images/thumb/0/0a/516403-2.6.jpg/aid516403-v4-728px-516403-2.6.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":"728","bigHeight":"485","licensing":"

Image by: Uploader
License: Creative Commons

"} Tape measure - this is invaluable for many sewing and mending projects{"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a1/516403-2.7.jpg/v4-459px-516403-2.7.jpg","bigUrl":"/images/thumb/a/a1/516403-2.7.jpg/aid516403-v4-728px-516403-2.7.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":"728","bigHeight":"485","licensing":"

Image by: Uploader
License: Creative Commons

"} A seam ripper - this is handy for quick hem mending{"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2b/516403-2.8.jpg/v4-459px-516403-2.8.jpg","bigUrl":"/images/thumb/2/2b/516403-2.8.jpg/aid516403-v4-728px-516403-2.8.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":"728","bigHeight":"485","licensing":"

Image by: Uploader
License: Creative Commons

"}

steps.headline: Place all items in the container.
steps.description: Over time, replenish items as they are used up and keep an eye on anything going rusty and replace it. Scrap fabric of any kind, shape, or size for testing threading on a sewing machine

text:
Find a suitable container to keep your sewing kit in. A little sewing basket or an open basket with a handle are ideal. Other choices include plastic boxes, tackle boxes, antique tins, cardboard boxes, etc. Gather together the following items for inclusion in the sewing kit:Needles - purchase a set of needles in differing sizes{"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4d/516403-2.1.jpg/v4-459px-516403-2.1.jpg","bigUrl":"/images/thumb/4/4d/516403-2.1.jpg/aid516403-v4-728px-516403-2.1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":"728","bigHeight":"485","licensing":"

Choose other colours as match items of clothing or favourite colours for clothes in your household. Over time you will build up your cotton collection with other colours and different thread types, such as metallic and invisible threads{"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bd/516403-2.4.jpg/v4-459px-516403-2.4.jpg","bigUrl":"/images/thumb/b/bd/516403-2.4.jpg/aid516403-v4-728px-516403-2.4.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":"728","bigHeight":"485","licensing":"
